Sure, single-payer would have been much better. But it wouldn't have passed. It has been tried over and again, these past 70 years, but the AMA has always been able to defeat it. FDR tried, Truman tried twice, and Ted Kennedy tried. The AMA called these plans Socialism, and they were all dead on arrival.
So, I don't agree with you because the ACA is a really big deal. Do you realize how much money will be taken from the rich and given to the poor and middle class in the form of health care? The subsidies are fabulous! And for the first time the rich will pay Medicare payroll taxes on their dividend and capital gains income. This is a first.
If you're really part of the Left, stop fighting with your brothers and sisters.
Joseph in Missoula

Neither Republicans nor Obama deserve much praise for the health care cost mess. Americans still pay twice what other people pay for health care, and the care we receive is worse. We have more dead babies and shorter lives.

Obama sold out to the insurance companies. He collaborated with lobbyists and corrupt legislators to guarantee an additional hundred million paying customers to the insurance industry, and received in return essentially nothing. Obamacare is a copy of Romneycare in Massachusetts. After ten years, costs in that state are as high as ever and neither care nor health outcomes have changed.

America needs Evidence Based Medicine, which the other twenty advanced countries have. They evaluate procedures are do not pay for ineffective or insanely expensive ones. Only the US pays customary charges for health procedures and makes no effort to determine which are effective. For the political story, read reporter Ron Suskind's book Confidence Men.

The Republicans, of course, offer no solutions and obstruct anything constructive. Their noses are in the insurance and medical company troughs along with the Democrats'.

We should pay what the other advanced countries pay, and we should do it either by single-payer or by non-profit insurance companies, like most other advanced nations.

For more great ideas go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (2 min5 sec). Laugh, cry, vote for Elizabeth Warren and contact me.

I read this piece with great interest, as someone who has been on the other side of the crash. The similarities are remarkable. When I was 17 years old, I killed a newlywed motorcyclist in front of his wife by making a swift left-land turn in front of him. I was not speeding, drunk, or texting, but I was distracted by searching for a building on the left side of the road. I "got away with it" by only being charged with minor traffic violations ("failure to yield"), but I spent years in treatment for PTSD, and, like the author, I also used EMDR in my recovery. The crash defined me for a long time. I still wake up with weights in my chest. I think of his wife and parents constantly.

It's tough to read all the comments about how the punishments for these drivers should be much harsher, to serve as a deterrent against distraction. I don't know that this is useful. The people I relate to most are the parents who have left babies in hot cars (recall Gene Weingarten's Pulizter prize-winning piece "Fatal Distraction"). If I had been drunk or texting, it would be easy for me to pinpoint something in myself that I could fix, that I could adequately punish. I realize this offends our sense of justice, that if I kill someone and only get a small fine, I've "gotten away" with it. But what else is there? I've spent a long time proving to myself that I will never, ever get away with it, but I'm left unsatisfied and heavyhearted.

I was hit from behind three and a half years ago, just as I was trying to cross my own one-way street.  I looked down the street, saw nothing coming and thought it was safe to cross.  The next second I had been whammed in the back -- by a car, reversing into an illegal "spot" -- and was smacked face-down on the street. I was lucky.  I did not lose consciousness.  After opening my eyes to see a lot of blood on the ground, I closed my eyes and started to pray.  My daughter's wedding was to take place in exactly one week.  I heard many people around me, offering help. A woman I did not know held my hand and told me an ambulance was on its way.  The EMT personnel were great, even though they had to cut my favorite denim jacket off me.  Six hours later, the ER at St. Luke's-Roosevelt released me, and I went home.  The next week, with the help of DermaBlend make-up, I looked decent enough for the wedding.  And I even danced.  I know how very, very fortunate I was.  But now I look both ways before crossing one-way streets.  And I harangue drivers who go backwards down the street to get to that precious parking space.

I applaude both mayor Bloomberg and DeBlasio for taking this issue on. Cars are a fact of life and have to adhere to a lot of rules. Most drivers obey the law most of the time, but more can be done to get drivers to operate safely.

Cyclist and pedestrians can also help. We can't get to zero fatilities without pedestrians and cyclist obeying the law.

We need more enforcement for all street users, including: anti jaywalking enforcement at high impact intersections; speeding enforcement; better drivers ed and safe commuting for students; and a requirement that all drivers take a saftey workshop every three years to retain their license.

First of all, what a human and touching expression of our fragility as humans, and what a reminder of how real that becomes with tons of steel tossing us around like a bean sack.

The police should be forced to walk or ride bikes at least half their time on the force. Their prejudice is completely with the invulnerable enclosure of their cars. And that prejudice has been reinforced by their 'musters' in our post-9-11 New York. The police instinct is to blame the pedestrian, and even more obstinately, to blame the Jay Walker, even though studies have demonstrated that those walking against the light with no traffic in sight are far safer than those walking with the light against right hand turns and inattentive drivers proximate and in motion.

We should have universal right hand pedestrian turn signals, and dedicated right hand turn car lanes that are on staggered lights as the commonplace standard rather than the exception. We also need police enforcement of right hand turns that do not grant pedestrian right of way. I have seen too many intentional bumps and pedestrian/vehicle contacts and especially trucks bearing down on pedestrians with a chilling homicidal aggression. Ditto with regard to express buses on their way to the terminal or the tunnel. This is not just true of NY. In fact in some small towns I've witnessed even more dumbfounding ignorance and failure to enforce pedestrian right of way on crosswalks. It is a statewide and perhaps national issue.

San Francisco has "scramble" intersections in multiple spots in the Financial District, there's one at 4th and Folsom in SOMA, and at the Church/Market/14th Street five streets come-together clusterf$*k in the Castro. They need to put more scrambles in ASAP because pedestrians and bicyclists keep getting killed.

One of the causes of pedestrian accidents: pedestrians not paying attention to traffic. I'll bet that some recent accidents took place while pedestrians were on their cell phones and electronic devices. Or, when motorists were driving and using their smart phones at the same time.These devices impair ones ability to to be focused on the incoming traffic (pedestrian or motorists). I have seen plenty of pedestrian crossing the street and not using the crosswalks. If electric cars ever catch on, matters will get worst because electric cars are quiet -our ears won't help keep us safe when crossing the street.
PAUL FEINER
Greenburgh, NY
